artist.name: Pink Floyd
artist.text:
It's hard to find a better instance of a rock band which shows how serious and artistic rock music can be other than Pink Floyd. Not everybody is willing to admit that about the Beatles, and other relevant rock bands may be far more obscure. But Pink Floyd? You can't go wrong with them! In some circles, enjoying them is a sign of worth; in others, it's unthinkable not to like them; in some, the coolest thing you can say is that [a]Piper at the Gates of Dawn[a] is, hands down, the best Pink Floyd album ever. You can't go wrong with them.

I'm not the greatest reader of music boards and discussions out there, but I don't recall ever seeing a lot people whining about Pink Floyd's popularity. Usually, popularity is a bad thing, because it supposedly "cheapens" the band's value. I think that's bullshit, of course, but that's just me. But with Pink Floyd, their hugeness and insane popularity only give them more credit. Yet, about 80% of the band's popularity is focused on about, what, 20% of their output. I could whine about that, I seriously could. But I won't. I mean, [a]Dark Side of the Moon[/a] set a record for the longest period for an album to stay on the charts, [a]The Wall[/a] sold like cupcakes and so on. How many people know about their pre-[a]Dark Side of the Moon[/a] period? How many know that a guy named Syd Barrett was actually one of the founding members of the band? Not a crowd, certainly, but guess what? Not everybody knows everything. That may not be news, but many people just seem to refuse to accept that. Yes, it's a shame that so much of the band's great material is relatively obscure, but the most I can do about it is review the albums and spread the word. Complaining will do nothing about it.

In case you never heard the band, well, you have to do it. They are hyped to all hell, they are a boring cliché, but that's just how huge and important they are! You may simply not enjoy their style at all, but the least you should know is just how unique and peculiar their style is. They rarely ever set out to "ROCK YOUR SOCKS OFF!", their music was usually slow, the guitars slippery and watery, the keyboards very prominent, and the arrangements and production extremely sofisticated and complex. And THAT is how they reached the pantheon of rock music: no sheer power, no rocking out, just a lot of weight and effort. And what is good about their music? The melodies? Not really: usually the melodic content of their music was just enough to give the songs something to bite and chew, and only sometimes does something truly jump out and grab your brain. So, the playing? Except for David Gilmour's ultra-hyped guitar solos, the band's performances were extremely restrained and limited to working in favour of the songs and nothing more, no showing-off and soloing only as much as necessary. So, the innovation? Well, in terms of pushing the envelope, the band was truly into it in their first years, to the point of producing some works that they consider as true missteps themselves, but on their more popular stage, they were more concerned with expanding their field and not with "innovating". So... what is it?

It's easy, or maybe too easy, to define Pink Floyd's strength as a perfect combination and balance of many different, fine-tuned elements. Pink Floyd's songs, and sometimes their albums as a whole, seem to reveal a whole vision, a whole world of atmosphere and texture before you. Even the simplest and most basic songs seem to receive a herculean amount of work to make them sound profound and interesting. This can have opposite results, of course: just as you can praise that effort and the sheer depth of their work, you can complain about how overproduced and heavyhanded the whole thing is. Which attitude you'll take is entirely up to you. Is either of them "wrong"? No, I don't think so. It just depends on which side of the board you happen to land on. I happened to land on the former, therefore I really appreciate the incredible depth and meticulousness of their output. And that's what you get: even the simplest ideas end up taking an unbelievably huge scope, and they use every resource to open that scope as wide as possible. Their albums are incredible experiences for one to lose himself in — you can just let yourself drift away in the music and the atmospheres. Of course, this is no ambient and no new-age: the music will grab your attention and refuse to let go. It's no background music or easy-listening, that's for sure.

All things considered, when first entering their catalogue, you can just go and pick up any of their "four big" 70's records ([a]Dark Side of the Moon[/a], [a]Wish You Were Here[/a], [a]Animals[/a] and [a]The Wall[/a]). You'll make no mistake: those records distill the very essence of the band ([a]The Wall[/a] a little less so, but even still, all four records are quite distinct), they are excellent AND accessible. But don't miss out on the earlier releases: [a]Meddle[/a], in particular, is worth a listen, and their earliest, "psychedelic" records, are fascinating in their own right. As for their later output... well, tread carefully. But suffice to say, you'll probably have to own all their studio records anyway, so just go for it. And DON'T MISS OUT the soundtracks — they are essential.
artist.comments:
Reader comments:

Sean Duvall (December 18, 2003):

Excuse me for a moment but I must correct you. To say that David Gilmour's guitar work is slow and over calculated and (good god) COLD? Is just wrong my friend. You're telling me the solo on 'Another Brick in the Wall' wasnt one of the best ever played? The tone was perfect, the phrasing sublime...I feel bad that you cant see it.
If I'm in the dark here please let me know what guitar players I should be listening to. Obviously I'm out of my fucking mind.
[editor's note: Well, that's pretty much it. These are the basic feelings I get when listening to Dave Gilmour, and I guess neither of us is wrong - after all, it's just a matter of taste. But like I said, there are moments when David pulls off something real great out of his guitar. 'Another Brick In The Wall, part 2' is a good example, and so is 'Echoes' like I mentioned above. But his work on stuff from A Momentary Lapse Of Reason and The Division Bell, and even 'classics' like 'Comfortably Numb' never hit any nerve on me. And that's really the opinion I hold. If you want suggestions of other guitarists, I wholeheartedly recommend Mike Oldfield with his Ommadawn, Tubular Bells and Amarok. And thanks for the comments. Feel free to send more.]

Jeff Stone (November 20, 2004):

I must agree with you as re: most of your Pink Floyd comments. However, I LOVE Fat Old Sun and Atom Heart Mother's one of PF's best tunes! Nice site, sir. The South Park characters add that extra frisson.

Best of luck with your music! I will recommend your site to others.

Regards
Straker

album.title: The Piper at the Gates of Dawn

track.title: Take Up Thy Stethoscope and Walk

album.review:
It's always a good idea to start from the beginning, especially when it comes to Pink Floyd. It has to be said, though, that their debut LP isn't even the proper "beginning" here. The Syd Barrett-led formation of Pink Floyd was known at the time mostly because of their wild, envelope-pushing live performances with huge, extended psychedelic jamming; a 3-minute ditty would basically turn into a 16-minute long sonic exploration with astral noise and whatever else they'd throw in the brew. In fact, when this album came out, some of the fanbase actually considered it disappointing, because it didn't mirror those performances, and the psychedelic noise and the astral jams are where it's at, maaaan.

Don't be misguided, though. If you're completely unfamiliar with this kind of music, you will still be utterly blown away by what you hear here. The jamming and the noise-making are here, but concentrated on a few of the tracks. The primary example of that is the opener of side B, the instrumental [s]Interstellar Overdrive[/s], which is pretty much the ultimate summation of the band's capabilities. It's bookended by a really mean, gruff, heavy riff, starting out with Syd plucking his guitar like there's no tomorrow, and the whole band crashing into a real blast. And then, it just keeps dissolving into dissonance, and turns into this massive, completely uncompromised... jam? I think it's demeaning to call this a "jam", because there's basically no concern for rhythm or structure or anything! No, sir, this is actually an experimental avant-garde composition, not a "jam". And while this thing would go on for 20 minutes or more in a live setting, the band and producer Norman Smith made the wise decision to keep this version trimmed down to 9 minutes, giving it a much bigger effect and raising its impact when placed along with the rest of the tracks. Imagine a whole side of this thing? It wouldn't really fit.

Everywhere else, the improvisational and exploratory aspect of the band is considerably more restrained, but not less exciting. [s]Astronomy Domine[/s] is a classic in every sense, with guitar work that combine the spaced-out starry-eyed with the heavy and menacing with absolute mastery, and a rhythm that sounds like it's constantly stubmling and crashing into you, instead of merely propelling itself forwards. Throw in Syd's evocative, alliterative lyrics, assorted studio effects and exhilarating band performance and you get one hell of a good reason to pick up this record. It had the harmful effect of making Pink Floyd pretty much synonymous with "space rock", and you should know that that's never been the case. However, if there is such a thing as "space rock", it wouldn't be such a stretch to say that [s]Astronomy Domine[/s] is the beginning and the end of it.

In other tracks, the band occasionally freaks out as well, but in a far more chaotic way. [s]Pow R Toc H[/s], for example, is basically an excuse for the band to go completely nuts with dissonance and bizarre animal noises (!!), dressed up in a pleasant little jazzy shuffle. I won't be a hypocrite and say I don't enjoy this, but it's much more of a little oddity rather than a true achievement. And there is Waters's [s]Take Up Thy Stethoscope and Walk[/s] (which is the only solo composition here that doesn't belong to Barrett), which is an awfully inane and obnoxious little "snippet" of a composition bookending an incredibly fast and whacked-out jam. Yes, the "song" portion is awful, but the jam is amazing! I can't help but enjoy it. Besides, in the studio, the jam went up to about 15 minutes, urging Norman Smith to do some severe editing and keep it down to three minutes. Phew! Smart move.

But Barrett is, first and foremost, a songwriter, and his skills in penning melodies and compositions is in full display here. Side two hosts some oddly folk-like, acoustic guitar laden tunes with fairy-tale lyrics such as [s]The Gnome[/s] and [s]The Scarecrow[/s], which is basically at complete odds with the rest of the album, but help a lot to create a slightly more complete picture of Barrett's world. [s]Chapter 24[/s] is more pot-induced than acid-induced, and uses the I Ching as source of inspiration, and maybe is a bit TOO slow and airy to create some substance, but it's still beautiful. Side one, however, has an amazing stretch of songs with begins with the aforementioned [s]Astronomy Domine[/s] and ends with [s]Flaming[/s]. [s]Lucifer Sam[/s] is head-spinningly fantastic, a sort of "surf-spy-rock" thing with an out-of-this-world guitar riff, fun lyrics about a cat, and entertaining band performances in the breaks between verses — even featuring Barrett using a bow on his guitar, and sounding much, much more fun and less ridiculous than Jimmy Page ever sounded. [s]Matilda Mother[/s] balances the psychedelic tendencies (check out that weird, menacing instrumental break with chilly whispers on top!) with Barrett's fascination with childhood and bedtime stories, all wrapped in a beautiful song, filled with tension-and-release. [s]Flaming[/s] is simply gorgeous and fun, featuring Barrett's most heartwarming and nice melodies in the album, and peppered with nice little "psychedelic" features.

Closing the album, there is the crazy, crazy [s]Bike[/s], with a very odd "stream of consciousness" vocal performance by Barrett and the band hilariously trying to keep track of his abrupt rhythmic left turns and unpredictable verse lengths. It's sort of like he doesn't give a damn about what they are playing behind him and just goes on singing whatever he feels like at the time. The result is odd, endearing and frightening all at once. It ends with an "illustration" of the "room of musical tunes" which already predicts the band's intense work with tape manipulation and sound effects in the future. The song must be heard to be believed, and it's oddly appropriate as a coda for the album. Is it representative? Heck, to this day I'm highly unsure about what track here is "representative". The best contenders are [s]Lucifer Sam[/s] and [s]Matilda Mother[/s], but certainly not [s]Astronomy Domine[/s] and [s]Interstellar Overdrive[/s]. Maybe these two were representative of the band's live act, but of the album? Don't even think about it. So, when you approach this album, be careful with your expectations. You'll not listen to the be-all-end-all of psychedelic avantgarde. It may take a while until you truly get what the album is, but then again, maybe you never will. And that is why the album is so legendary.

album.title: A Saucerful of Secrets

track.title: Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun

album.review:
The most notable thing about Syd Barrett, aside from his groundbreaking guitar work and knack for grandiose, spaced-out writing, is the complete decline of his mental health. The story of his decadence is widely documented, told and retold in books and all over the Intnernet, so I won't be boring to tell it all over again, since I have nothing do add. The consequences of Barrett's fall were pretty severe, and the band was on the brink of collapse. Syd would ruin their live performances by "zoning out" and becoming completely alienated from the band and the audience, walking out mid-song and so on — well, most of the audience probably found his antics very cool and cosmic, maaaan, but the band was getting fed up with it and brought David Gilmour to act as a "contingency plan", by stepping in when Syd would zone out. Eventually, they decided to simply not pick up Syd on the way to a gig, but decided to keep him in the band as a songwriter and studio musician. Therefore, for a short while, they were a five piece band, and this album is the only document we have of that phase.

Still, only a few tracks here have Barrett's participation, and he composed only one song here. During the recordings, he left the band, after a series of misfortunes and sorry incidents. In my opinion, one of the most remarkable stories regarding this phase is when Barrett arrived to rehearsal one day with a new song called "Have You Got It Yet?", which was essentially a practical joke on the band, with Barrett changing the verses every time the band tried to join, while the chorus consisted of Barrett singing "Have you got it yet?" to the band. Eventually Waters walked out and never played with Syd again. It's hard for a story to be so hilarious and so depressing at the same time. But yeah, that pretty much illustrates the state of the band back then: Syd was on his way out, and the band had no idea of what to do. The only clue they had was to try to keep on doing exactly what they were already doing, and try to emulate Barrett's imagination and wackiness. The result is a definite far cry from [a]Piper at the Gates of Dawn[/a], and also shows a band pretty much without future, not only due to the lack of a musical leader, but also to the mistrust of the managers.

The band's biggest bet here was on the title track, an 11 minute psychedelic instrumental powerhouse, which on studio takes the form of an extremely elaborate work, and live would become a hellish beast. The main difference between this one and [s]Interstellar Overdrive[/s] is that [s]A Saucerful of Secrets[/s] is carefully structured and planned-out beforehand. It isn't merely free improvisation and experimentation on the spot. Quite the contrary: they were willing to see how far they could get on studio. The finished product is a piece that counts more on dynamics than on wild instrument flailing, and it even has an almost cathartic ending, with David Gilmour supplying wordless vocal harmonies. It's less noisy and daring, and whether that's good or bad, depends entirely on you.

Well, I think it's great. The song more than shows that the band has more than enough material to keep going, and it also shows that the band doesn't seem very in the mood for being "psychedelic". I would dare say that there is nothing "psychedelic" about this track; it's more related with science fiction than psychedelic. Okay, so [s]Astronomy Domine[/s] was all "space rock" too, but compare the two tracks and you'll hear what I mean. On the rest of the album, though, the attempts at being psychedelic are painfully obvious. They even "psych-up" Rick Wright's two songs, which are basically inoffensive, tuneful ballads. [s]Remember a Day[/s] suffers the most from it, and it doesn't help that the song isn't really very melodically strong, but it is still a good, atmospheric effort. Now [s]See Saw[/s] is a great one, tuneful, wistful and delicately bittersweet. And not even the "psychedelic" noise outbursts could spoil this one. Wright's understated vocal delivery does this one a real favour, as well as the high pitched falsettos. In my opinion, this is the first true great Wright songs; and there are many yet to come, just to keep you informed.

Most other songs fall very strictly on the "psychedelic" camp, with little subtlety and no holds barred. Yet, they aren't all completely alike. The "classic" [s]Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun[/s] is, oddly enough, on the "meditative" side of psychedelia, which means: haunting and ominous bass line, sparse percussion, Waters semi-singing-semi-whispering, and even ambient "nature" sounds. I don't know why, but on live settings, they'd take this and turn it into a buffed-up psychedelic powerhouse. In here, the song doesn't really grab much of my attention; the main melody is a good one, but there doesn't seem to be a truly woven atmosphere in it. [s]Let There Be More Light[/s] swings all the way to the opposite way of the spectrum, straight into space-sci-fi-mumbo-jumbo with very radical dynamics between quiet and mantraic verses ("far-far-far-far away-way people heard him say-ay" and so on) and the loud 'n' blaring choruses. The two noteworthy moments in the track, though, are: the extra-cool intro with Waters delivering a fast bass riff, complete with organs and cymbal hits; and the coda, with David Gilmour displaying his famed, trademark guitar solo style: slow and methodic, letting the notes linger for as long as they may. This solo doesn't hit my nerves at all, though the band does bring up a pretty convincing sound-fest around him. Worth a listen.

The two remaining songs are more interesting cases. [s]Corporal Clegg[/s] features some dark humour with Waters talking about a disabled war veteran with an alcoholic wife. The music may be a little over-the-top and chaotic, but it works wonders in this context. It almost makes me believe that the band's "psychedelic" style, at this point, works best as humour as anything else — which is by no means an insult, after all, Syd Barrett did have a sense of humour. Besides, the way they combine ominous and mean guitar riffs, exaggerated vocal deliveries and a military march led by a kazoo is pretty brilliant. Not genius, but brilliant enough for me to award it a little red cross. As for [s]Jugband Blues[/s], Barrett's only composition in the album and last Barrett composition to appear on a Pink Floyd studio album, it already displays his lack of touch with reality. The lyrics are disjointed and almost meaningless. Almost: Barrett sings about his absence, as if he already knew his fate. The melody is just as disjointed as the lyrics, and the only thing that really keeps this song together is the imaginative arrangement, featuring even a brass band. Oh, yes, and the ending with Barrett alone with his guitar is gut-wrenching. It's obvious that this was the way for the band to give him a — fully deserved — nod of respect. In spite of all the flaws, it's impossible to deny that the song is a wonderous achievement. Yes, it's a weird conclusion for a weird album. For those who want to "document" the musical evolution of Pink Floyd, this album is a necessity. But it's heavily transitional, hit-or-miss nature may put off a few. For those who are interested mainly in their best material, this is not really very recommended; if you're thinking of getting it solely for the title track, well, there is [a]Ummagumma[/a], which may be a more compelling and interesting acquisition overall.

album.title: Soundtrack from the film More
album.review:
There is a fact that many people are willing to overlook: a soundtrack album is, in many ways, very different from a studio album, and it's indeed hard to listen to a soundtrack record without thinking "oh, this was merely made to follow a film" (unless we're talking about Vangelis, but let's not make unfair comparisons, shall we?). But the truth is that a soundtrack album has the potential of unearthing aspects of a band that a regular studio album may never reveal. A band that puts itself on a different modus operandi is naturally going to produce uncommon results; and in some cases, this can greatly help a band to grow and evolve. I do believe that's the case with this record, a soundtrack to a film by Barbet Schroeder which I have never watched. It seems to be a good film, but I never felt compelled to watch it anyway, and it won't help you "understand" the album any better either way.

Thing is, it's easy to overlook this album, but I don't think it has any less merits than [a]A Saucerful of Secrets[/a]. In fact, it has More (ha!): though the music is still tinged with psychedelia, it is neither exaggerated or forced, and this allows the music to truly flourish. We have songs here that are only concerned with being good songs, without asking every 10 seconds "Am I psychedelic enough?". And the instrumentals and noisy freak-outs all have a sense of purpose and direction. In short, the band doesn't have to prove anything; after all, if they were asked to do this soundtrack, it's because they already proved their worth, right? So, don't be put off by the "soundtrack" stigma. In fact, get this before [a]A Saucerful of Secrets[/a] if you are willing to.

Not don't go thinking that this is a "hidden masterpiece" or something like that. It's not a "masterpiece": side 2, in particular, gets kind of tiresome and aimless, and the highlights of the record can't be compared to the highlights of the band's overall career. But as far as their early career goes, this album is a revelation, and an important key in unlocking some of the band's secrets. The "avant-garde" bits have quite a lot of worth. The only place in which they let their sounds drag on and on is [s]Quicksilver[/s], which is not actively bad or anything, but it doesn't achieve much in all its seven minutes of "sonic exploration" — it tries to be ominous and quiet, but doesn't really succeed. There's also the band playing the blues ([s]More Blues[/s]), a sort of stupid gag with Waters and Gilmour playing some quite cool Spanish guitar and Gilmour impersonating an unfunny stereotype ([s]A Spanish Piece[/s] — ain't it good how these titles are self-descriptive?), the whole band playing bongos and congas in a faux-African setting ([s]Party Sequence[/s]) and a really cool jazzy exchange between Nick Mason (man, listen to those drums! The guy could really play!) and Rick Wright. This kind of variety would be completly unlikely in other places, isn't it? Besides that, where else could we hear Pink Floyd doing heavy metal? [s]The Nile Song[/s] became something of a minor classic, with distorted guitars, powerhouse drums aplenty and Gilmour shouting his lungs off. But the most memorable thing is the trick of raising the song a full tone at the end of every verse. [s]Ibiza Bar[/s] doesn't have the same luck, unfortunately, even though it has a nice quiet section at every verse. Both songs are pretty cool, indeed.

The [s]Main Theme[/s] is also a minor highlight, boasting a cool, jazzy groove and a spaced out atmosphere that's convincing and relaxed. I also love that Farfisa organ sound that Wright produces. This is a fine indication that the band was getting mature, and already had a much clearer idea of what they wanted to do. But what about the "non-avant-garde" tunes? Well, you probably wouldn't guess, but they more folk than anything else, and you don't need to get past the opening track to hear that: [s]Cirrus Minor[/s] is led only by Roger Waters on voice and guitar, with Wright adding some Farfisa organ for good measure. The melody is as simple as you can get, but it's so convincing and beautiful it's almost scary! I mean, where did they pull that off? Of course, being purely folk is not good enough: they complete it with a gorgeous coda led almost entirely by Wright on the organ, with some tape sounds and effects completing the scene. It's a tremendously good song. Likewise is [s]Cymbaline[/s], a more rock based ballad with a slightly ominous atmosphere and a melody to kill for, which also boasts a brilliantly atmospheric coda. [s]Green Is the Colour[/s] and [s]Crying Song[/s] are shorter and cuter; I've always been a great fan of the earlier, which combines simplicity and beauty in a way that the grating tin whistle (played by Nick Mason's wife) couldn't spoil even if it tried to, and the latter is surprisingly great with its very hushed mood.

I am sure that, if this material were worked into a more cohesive and coerent work and freed of the "soundtrack" label, it would have easily become a minor classic. I'm tempted to give this album a bigger rating than I gave to [a]A Saucerful of Secrets[/a], and I can say that this album is sort of in between a 10 and an 11. I just don't give it an 11 because of the overall lack of cohesion and some unconvincing tracks. But the uninitiated should try this out eventually.

album.title: Ummagumma

track.title: Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun
Several Species of Small Furry Animals Gathered Together in a Cave and Grooving with a Pict
The Grand Vizier's Garden Party: Entrance
The Grand Vizier's Garden Party: Entertainment
The Grand Vizier's Garden Party: Exit

album.review:
There's no more appropriate way for me to call this album than "Crossroads". The nature and the origin of the album are both very confused, and it sounds like the band really didn't know what they wanted to do next. This was originally meant to be a live album, featuring the staples of their most psychedelic period, but then they had the idea of splitting the second LP in four parts, with each member recording a solo piece. So, this album is half live-psychedelic, half avant-garde-freak-out. And what I gotta say is that, at this point in their career, the band didn't quite have the chops to make a masterpiece out of that.

The four tracks on disc one were collected from two live performances, and as you can see, the only "new" title is [s]Careful with That Axe, Eugene[/s], which is excellent in every aspect. it doesn't waste a single second of its running length, and develops steadily through gentle variations of intensity and mood. The playing is extraordinarily simple: Waters's bass lines are minimal, while Mason and Wright sprinkle their drum+organ combo in the right doses and Waters builds some additional tension with floating, wordless falsettos. But that's only until the sudden turnaround halfway through, when all the built tension erupts with Gilmour unleasing his guitar and Waters producing an unbelievable, gut-wrenching shriek. This is how you do a psychedelic instrumental, dammit! No chord changes are necessary, no freaky sound effects are needed — just an extraordinarily tight bandwork and a clever song construction. The album is worth having for this track alone, and you may be sure that's saying quite a lot.

As for the other three, I'll be very honest: only [s]Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun[/s] happens to improve on the album version. But maybe that's just because I never liked much the "meditation" atmosphere of it, and this noisier, more chaotic and dynamic version actually develops something worthwhile. [s]Astronomy Domine[/s] happens to sound way too meek and tame for my tastes, as if they mercilessly stripped the song of everything that made it so good in the first place. The only added a passage with Wright playing the organ nearly "a capella", which is noteworthy, but being surrounded with such a flaccid performance, its effect is pretty much lost. On the other hand, [s]A Saucerful of Secret[/s] fails for being too over-the-top. Mason does an excellent job in keeping up with that drum loop, and I think that's the best thing about the track. The ending replaces the heavenly vocal harmonies (which, I guess, they had no way of reproducing live) with a massive climax, leaving poor David Gilmour to carry the vocals all on his own. He definitely pulls off a valiant effort, but man, do I wish they had kept it entirely instrumental.

The studio record is, as you must have expected, a complete mess, a mixed bag of hit-and-miss material. But it's a lot, lot more interesting than the first record, and it's the only place in which you'll hear such avant-garde and unrestrained material from the band. Listening to this, it becomes pretty clear that only Wright and Waters were fully prepared to take on this project. Mason had to ask for the help of avant-garde musician Ron Geesin to put together the flute intro and outro of [s]The Grand Vizier's Garden Party[/s], played by Mason's wife, Lindy. The main part is, as should be expected, mostly drum and percussion dominated, though he spends much of it with tape experiments, and only in the few final minute he does play a drum solo. Gilmour's piece, [s]The Narrow Way[/s], sounds far more accomplished, even though its also mostly a "hodge-podge" of stuff; but he really puts his guitars to work on those pieces, creating an accoustic joyful little thing on part 1, a very eerie and menacing overdriven guitar riff on part 2, and finally delivering a song with vocals and lyrics on part 3, which is surprisingly good and well performed, and pretty much sets the standard for other Pink Floyd songs that would come along. Even though it does feature some tape manipulation and effects, Gilmour's work is the most straightforward in the album.

Wright's work, on the other hand, is by far the most avantgarde. [s]Sysyphus[/s] is completely unabashed and unmodest, completely going for something that is more "neo-classical" than "rock" at all. Wright uses timpani, percussion and Mellotrons to create a pseudo-orchestral sound in the thunderous opening theme, which moves on to a solo piano piece. At first you may think that you've got the hang of it, with pretty piano chords and contemplative semi-melodies and so on, but that only lasts for a few minutes, and shortly the whole atmosphere is wrecked mercilessly. And the following part only makes things more radical, with Wright manipulating the piano strings directly and throwing in all kinds of percussion effects and tape manipulations. There are really no moderation here: he is truly out to make the most upsetting and disturbing sound with whatever tools he had available to him. Yet, the composition as a whole is beautifully framed and complete: the second half of the composition ties it all together with a lengthy, contemplative passage on a Mellotron, which stumbled into a massive and definitive grand finale. What a trip, man! Now you see how it is when the musician knows exactly what he is doing.

Waters's contributions are, by far, the oddest. [s]Grantchester Meadows[/s] may seem ominous with its length, but it's actually a folk tune played entirely on acoustic guitar. It's even more straightforward than [s]Cirrus Minor[/s], and the only bit of "experimentation" is the addition of sounds of animals and other "ambience" effects. The second track, however, is a major experiment with tape manipulation, featuring mainly vocal sounds played on high speeds, body slapping, tapping on the microphone and so on, all with the objective of creating exactly what the title of the track describes. And it works! I doube that Waters intended it as a "serious art statement", as it seems extremely facetious, especially when he suddenly goes on a long rant at the end with an exaggerated Scottish accent. It's a piece of humour, and a great one. In this way, you can argue that only Waters truly understood the meaning of the album. But then again, maybe the band members were right when they said there was just no meaning at all: is a meaning even necessary? I don't think so. Fact is, the album is horribly inconsistent, but it is an extremely unique item in the band's catalogue. You have to listen to it, if only to say that you did listen.

album.title: Atom Heart Mother
album.review:
Boy, it sure can be difficult listening to a band that has no idea of what they want to do. But then again, what fault do they have? Even though the only real masterpiece they had released so far was their debut album — which was, in turn, the brainchild of Syd Barrett, who was long gone — they were praised to death by basically everyone, their live performances were highly successful, and, in short, they were BIG. But they just didn't know how to translate that BIGness to an LP. In other words, they had no idea how they were supposed to match people's expectations. This album was clearly an attempt, though. They were trying.

The title track is 24 minutes long and is entirely instrumental. Its main portion was based on a sequence of chords Gilmour came up, and it was mostly a matter of sticking pieces together until they didn't fall off, and recording it as best as they could. But it still needed that avant-garde boost, so they passed the tapes to Ron Geesin, who proceeded to write and record an elaborate orchestral arrangement with plenty of brass and choir, while the band was out touring. When they were back, they weren't quite satisfied with the recording as it was (there were several synchronization problem between the band and the orchestra, result of Geesing having to record on top of an already recorded tape) and wanted to do it all over again, but the EMI execs gave them the red light. So, they put out what they had, the album was largely well received, and the band went on having extremely mixed feelings about it. Waters repeatedly said he hated the track, while the others were warmer towards it. But fact is, the song remained a staple of their live shows for quite a few years.

Basically, the best thing about the song is its scope and its confidence. Well, I don't know, it does sound like the band knows what they're doing all the way through; but maybe that is largely the merit of Ron Geesin, who was able to use his orchestrations to fill in the blanks left deliberately by the band on the recording. You don't hear a band on the top of their game, but you hear a geniune effort to come up with a piece that could stand on its own two feet. And, well, it goes on for 24 minutes, and never does it falter. It's not a masterpiece, by no means, but taken as a whole, it's far superior to the "sum of the parts" of the last albums. Another thing that pleases is that the band doesn't force anything: much of the song is devoted to a very straightforward, slightly mournful ballad (Gilmour's theme), which is complemented by some very melodic additions by Waters, Wright and Co. It never pushes its "avant-gardeness" down the listener's throat, and when it eventually switches gears and goes into elongated band jams, abstract "scat-singing" by the choir, and even a hellish collage of tape effects and whatnot, the transitions happen naturally, and always with a sense of direction. It's not an inconsequent hackjob at all: it's a fairly mature piece. I don't think that rerecording the track would have turned it into a full masterpiece, really: the problems with the track are mostly technical, though it's quite probable they would have changed a lot of things if they had had the chance. But [s]Atom Heart Mother[/s] is something to be happy with. I'm happy with it. Waters isn't, but he is not the reviewer here, right?

But then, I did say that the band didn't know what they were doing. That is still true: [s]Atom Heart Mother[/s] grew as a sort of organic thing, with litttle or no foresight. And the second side of the album is even worse in this aspect: we have three "solo" songs from the three songwriters in the band (they are all full band performances, but each composer wrote on his own), and a collaborative 13-minute piece called [s]Alan's Psychedelic Breakfast[/s], which is the kind of track that sounds awesome on paper but, on tape, leaves a little to be desired. The idea was to create a "musical breakfast", with pieces of music interwoven with sounds of roadie Alan Styles making and eating breakfast, and it probably was really fun to perform life and such. But on record, it sounds merely like three pieces of pleasant, folk-tinged acoustic instrumental music joined together with assorted kitchen sounds. The "breakfast" is not truly integrated with the music or vice versa, and it ends up sounding a little lazy, a lacklustre execution for a pretty good idea. But the music is pretty, all three segments, especially the last one; and it's sort of funny hearing Alan muttering randomly among all the different noises.

Now, the three songs are a major winning streak. Waters's [s]If[/s] and Gilmour's [s]Far Old Sun[/s] are very understated and mellow — particularly [s]If[/s], which is pretty much on the "depressing" side of the scale, gorgeously written and played just with the right amount of feeling and tenderness; really, the band is on an all time high here — while [s]Fat Old Sun[/s] is more uplifting, and already shows a big tendency of David Gilmour of closing his songs with very lengthy guitar solos. But the song is really good, and the soloing doesn't get to the point of being annoying, though it does have that traditional Gilmour thing of never really taking off. You know, a solo must somehow grab your full attention and keep you on the edge of your seat, otherwise it's not soloing, but just noodling, ya know. It's unfair to say that Gilmour is noodling here, but he just seems content with "extracting pretty sounds" without delivering a truly massive payload. Oh, what the hell. Either way, Wright's [s]Summer '68[/s] is easily, easily the best thing in the record, a highlight to end all highlights. It is a true wonder of song construction and arrangement, moving from part to part with grace and elegance, with surprising twists of arrangement (the big entrance of the full brass band halfway through are certain to get my hairs standing on end), and connecting it all together with beautiful melodymaking. This is easily Floyd's best song in the post-Barrett-pre-[a]Meddle[/a] period, full stop. And you know what's interesting? Even though the song doesn't sound very "psychedelic" at all, it was used, with great effect, in a pretty "psychedelic" advertising montage which led to a Brazilian TV news program in the early 70's, and you can see it here. Pretty amazing.

As for the record, just don't be misled by the hype around it. The album cover is an extremely iconic classic, and overall the name "Atom Heart Mother" always raises a few ears when it's mentioned; but that is more because this album was a breakthrough for the band. Or, more properly, this album broke the doors open, and they would truly move on through on the next record. It is a seminal release, but not an outstanding classic. It deserves praise, it's a must hear for any Floyd fan, and if you're getting interested in the band, you'll have to get it eventually. Just don't expect a masterpiece and you'll be alright.

album.title: Meddle
album.review:
At least, we reach the album that showed to the world just exactly what these four guys were up to all the time. This is the first time we hear the band truly joining forces to produce a coherent and consistent album, you know: instead of staggering to fill up the sides of the record with material, it seems like the band clearly wanted to push the boundaries and stretch their abilities to their limit. And the effort pays off, and how!

For one, this album nails down the unique, inimitable "sound" of Pink Floyd, watery, fluid, spacey and profoundly organic. And what better place to check it out than in the 23-minute-long tour de force [s]Echoes[/s], which occupies the entire second side? You may be led to think this is [s]Atom Heart Mother II[/s], but that couldn't be further from the truth. This time around, the band relied entirely on their own composition, arrangement and production skills, and worked hard to combine ideas and form a very large, complete whole that works on its own. It is well documented that the whole composition sparked out of a single, very high piano note (a B6, if I'm not mistaken), which was sent through a rotating speaker (the Leslie, which is actually not a "rotating speaker" — only the horns inside the speaker actually rotate), and the result is the sound that opens the track. But from that point on, the song develops marvellously, with vocals shared by Wright and Gilmour, and a full, beautiful sound aided by Wright's Farfisa organ and a memorable "descending" guitar riff that Waters claimed were plagiarised on Andrew Lloyd Webber's theme from The Phantom of the Opera. The instrumental segues that make up the inner portion of the song are all marvellously performed and integrated with the rest of the material, including the polarising "noise-making" part in the middle. I'll probably sound corny saying this, but this is the perfect music for you to "lose yourself" into. It is a complete journey, and once you manage to dig into its core, you'll never want to leave. It's extremely rewarding.

Side A, however, does not end up as a letdown; though it was a wise idea to leave [s]Echoes[/s] on side B, as it is pretty much impossible to follow up that track with anything. Besides, [s]One of These Days[/s] is a brilliant album opener, and by far the most vicious and ominous thing they band recorded to this point. Well, maybe only second to [s]Careful with That Axe, Eugene[/s]; but [s]One of These Days[/s] packs a much bigger punch in a much more condensed form, and it's carried mostly by Waters and Gilmour playing a one-note bass riff simultaneously, ran through an echo effect. The result must be heard to be believed, and to top it off, the band spices it with Wright's organ effects, backwards percussion hits and Gilmour's heavy guitar chords. Eventually, the whole band crashes in for a grand finale with Gilmour putting his soloing skills to maximum effect. But this is the only truly all-out rockin' track on the album, but with a song this good, it's silly to ask for more. Everywhere else you get more of that classic watery sound, and the only difference between side A and side B, in terms of texture, is a much smaller reliance on Wright's keyboards: while on [s]Echoes[/s] we have loads of Farfisa organ, Hammond organ, piano and whatever else, the four songs are far more guitar based, and both Waters and Gilmour make their contributions. [s]A Pillow of Winds[/s] features a kind of gorgeousness not found anywhere else in the band's catalogue so far. Really! Give it a listen and see if you can find anything similar. The mixture of gently picking acoustic guitars and Gilmour's slide is a gift from Heaven, and even the vocal melody is pretty much an accessory. Towards the end the band adds a faint tinge of organ and Mason's hi-hat, just for extra spice, and the effect is tremendous. Meanwhile, [s]Fearless[/s] is a wonderful, robust, memorable song, featuring a vocal melody and a repeated ascending guitar riff to kill for. Interestingly, Gilmour's singing voice are used to great effect on both songs, with its hushed, mellow quality. [s]Fearless[/s] also displays the band's increasing mastery of arrangements, switching beautifully between the jangly and rhythmic verses and the gently floating choruses.

The side is closed with two far less dense and more relaxed songs, which are surprisingly maligned by a portion of fans. Okay, so [s]Seamus[/s] is indeed entirely based on a pretty grating gimmick: it's a short piece of generic blues in which Gilmour "duets" with the eponymous dog, which howls his way through the entire track. But it is funny! And it is cute! Okay, so a dog's howl isn't exactly the most pleasant of sounds, but the band intended to do a little, unpretentious musical joke, and they succeeded. [s]Saint Tropez[/s], on the other hand, doesn't have anything grating or annoying at all: just Waters pulling off an enjoyable, catchy little jazzy tune with some soloing on slide guitar and on piano. Just that. And the band pulls it off surprisingly well. The tunes are pretty much at odds with the rest of the material, but they arrive as a breather of fresh air before the magnum opus on side B. In my book, that's a smart, unexpected move, and it improves the album overall. I don't share the view that the album would be better off without those tracks, and unless anyone can prove they could have written another stupendous track to replace them, I stand by my opinion. It's not that I consider this album perfect, but it is a prodigious work, and we can finally hear Pink Floyd on full flight here. Or, to be more precise, almost. But let's go by parts, shall we?

album.title: Obscured by Clouds
album.review:
In 1972, the band took a break from the sessions of their next album to record the soundtrack for the French film La Valée, directed by Barbet Schroeder (same director of More). Oddly enough, this album doesn't sound at all like a sountrack on first listen, as most of the album consists of short, friendly tunes, and most of them with vocals. There are no spaced out sonic explorations, no short interlinking pieces, no unexplainable gags, and the only truly soundtrackish piece is the closing track (which is kinda lame, truth be told). In short, the only thing that hints that this is not a "regular" Pink Floyd album is its rather unpolished nature, due to the extremely tight deadline the band had when recording the music.

There are two notable things about this record. The first is the use of synthesizers, which was new to the band. They employ a VCS3 analogue synth, which would be a key piece of their next album. The second thing is that some of these tracks are really good. And, this being a soundtrack, the band was free to poke at some places they would usually not poke at; for example, drivin' hard rock, which Gilmour dabbles with on [s]The Gold It's in the...[/s], which is surprisingly fun and engaging. Gilmour's guitar is really good here, and about half of it is a guitar solo that really keeps up the level of fun. On the other end of the spectrum is [s]Childhood's End[/s], which is pretty bitter and angry, and boasts a funkish, chopped rhythm that also represents a step towards the band's near future. And what's with that atmospheric, synth-laden intro? Whoa! Not even [a]Meddle[/a] was so bold in integrating pop tunes with experimentation such as this! Okay, [s]Fearless[/s] had the football chant and all, but that was something else. Anyway, in case you haven't listened to [a]Dark Side of the Moon[/a] yet, give this song a listen on YouTube or something before you move on. Keep that song in mind.

Waters's contribution is just as surprising as his folky digressions: [s]Free Four[/s] tackles the subject of war and death in an extremely bitter, sorrowful tone (which would become very, very typical for him), but on top of a jangly and joyful music. The way the sung verses lead into a bumpy, playful "baaam!" synth chord, as well as the harder-edged instrumental passages, only increase the fun factor of the song. This kind of smart, twisted sense of humour would not be common at all in the next records. As for the other songs, they are all ballads. Gilmour's [s]Wots... uh, the Deal?[/s] is particularly beautiful, with a gentle, but aching delivery and a measured, exquisite performance by the whole band. And once again Gilmour pulls out his slide guitar for great effect. [s]Burning Bridges[/s] is also beautiful, maybe a bit too draggy for its own sake, but featuring a really beautiful keyboard pattern on Wright's Hammond organ. Only Wright's collaboration with Waters, [s]Stay[/s], sounds way too generic and bland to cause an impression, in spite of the dramatic and catchy chorus. Sorry, Rick.

But there are instrumentals in the album, too, and the only one that's really hard on the ears is the aforementioned album closer [s]Absolutely Curtains[/s], which consists largely of Wright making ambience on his keyboards and Mason creating dynamics on timpani and cymbals. It drags on for too long and too aimlessly; I think Wright's playing suffers when there's no real musical theme being delivered, and this would become very, very clear on some of his later pieces (in fact, if you've heard his solo piano piece written for Michelangelo Antonioni's infamous film Zabriskie Point, entitled [s]The Violent Sequence[/s], you probably know what I mean). Many people complain about the elongated coda of the track, featuring an aboryginal chant, but I actually think that's the best part of the song. Maybe the voices will sound too foreign to you, but hey! maybe it's time for you to look at some things beyond your national frontiers, right?

The pair of opening tracks actually form a suite, and it sounds far groovier, spaced-out and psychedelic than anything the band recorded since, um, since [a]More[/a]! The title track has some synth drones and a mechanical, dull drum loop serving as a foundation for a cool, slightly bluesy guitar solo by Gilmour, and on [s]When You're In[/s], the whole band crashes in with a riff based on power chords. Really good stuff! Definitely worth checking out. To end the namedrops, [s]Mudmen[/s] is an unbelievably slow, morose ballad extending on the main theme of [s]Burning Bridges[/s]. But it sounds really beautiful, and the slowness is actually an asset here: the dramatic chord changes and the huge climaxes on the choruses work extremely well. It's a great piece. So, if you like this band, do yourself a favour and give this album a spin once in a while. It may not be [a]Meddle[/a], and not even a very adequate record for converting the unfaithful and making the join the ranks of Floyd followers, but in all aspects, this is the same Pink Floyd we've grown to love and respect. Yes, with a few tracks and a slightly rough-around-the-edges feel. But if you've already got [a]A Saucerful of Secrets[/a], there's no reason to neglect this one.

album.title: Dark Side of the Moon

track.title: The Great Gig in the Sky

album.review:
It may not be very evident in my reviews, but I don't like making assumptions about any of my readers (yes, both of you!). So, if you have never heard a single minute off this album, worry not: this review is for you.

If you look at the history of Floyd's albums so far, you'see that nearly all of them came off as a result of a pretty difficult process. Even [a]Meddle[/a] had to go through a fair bit of staggering before being completed. For their next release, they decided to let the musical ideas mature a lot more before committing them to tape, and this way, a suite of songs was formed and performed in nearly all of their live performances. That suite eventually became this album, and that explains why the album sounds so coherent and confident, to the point of making [a]Meddle[/a] sound almost like a mere rehearsal. Not only all songs here are built on very deep and strong foundations, but the album incorporates many studio techniques in quite novel ways, with really innovative results. This merit belongs not solely to the band, but also to engineer Alan Parsons, and it's absolutely necessary to do that justice. Parsons was responsible by several solutions and effects employed on the album. But that brings up another mistake many people make: the sound effects, elaborate recordings of ringing clocks, tape collages and excerpts of people giving interviews are not what make this album so distinctive. The musical material here is supreme, and taken as a whole, easily beats all their previous records. It's not terribly productive to talk about isolated songs in here: just recall how [s]Echoes[/s] presented 23 minutes of glory, extend that to 40 minutes, and you get this album. Essentially.

Now, the band was not new to including all kinds of sounds and recording in their albums, as well as using studio effects and tricks to enhance their music (remember the echo unit on [s]One of These Days[/s], the piano-on-a-Leslie of [s]Echoes[/s], the synthesizer soundscape of [s]Childhood's End[/s], etc.). But in this album, all that accumulated skill and experience favour the entire album, not just a few select tracks. The VCS3 synthesizer returns to play some key roles, the stereo-ping-pong echoes are very present, and the sound effects are very intelligently integrated in the songs. It's important to mention that this, unlike the previous records, is a concept album. Waters wrote all lyrics, and they are all interlinked to form a bigger statement; so instead of abstract sonic landscapes and football chants, you have a room full of deafening ringing clocks to represent the ruthlessness of passing time, a dance of cash registers and falling coins making a rhythm, voices of people answering questions related to fighting, death and insanity, and so on and on. If you're pretentious enough, you can say this album is more of a "tone poem" than a mere rock album, and I won't argue against you. This is not a band toying around with ideas or struggling to make something work: this is a band with a complete idea of what they want and a complete idea of how to get there.

With this fairly odd construction, though, it's fairly easy for people to dismiss the album as a collection of weak, pale songs tied together with novelty noisemaking; and knowing how this is one of the best selling albums of all time, such backlash is only to be expected.
